intro: Lepidaploa sororia, commonly known as the mountain sorrel, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the high-altitude regions of South America. It belongs to the Polygonaceae family, which includes plants such as buckwheat and sorrel. The plant features upright stems that are often tinged with red, and its leaves are alternate, ovate, and covered in a dense layer of fine hairs. Lepidaploa sororia produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in clusters, and it thrives in cool, moist environments. Due to its unique adaptations to high-altitude conditions, it is considered an important species in ecological studies of alpine flora.
